title: Lifestyle Expectations
description: Assess how aligned you feel about lifestyle and money

questions.text: I feel my partner and I have compatible lifestyle expectations.

therapeutic.rationale: Lifestyle expectations—where you live, how you travel, what you own—have financial implications. Compatible expectations reduce future conflict about spending.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: A compatibility gap deserves honest conversation. Different expectations aren't deal-breakers but need acknowledgment and negotiation.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared lifestyle expectations create alignment about what you're building toward financially.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What lifestyle do you envision for yourself? Does your partner share this vision?

questions.text: I trust my partner doesn't expect me to financially overextend.

therapeutic.rationale: Trust that your partner won't pressure you to spend beyond your means creates safety. Partners who feel pressured to maintain certain lifestyles experience ongoing stress.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner feels pressure to overextend, discuss expectations openly. The other partner may not realize the stress they're creating.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual trust about not overextending creates financial security.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you ever feel pressure to spend more than you're comfortable with?

questions.text: I feel we can be happy without needing expensive things.

therapeutic.rationale: Belief that your happiness doesn't depend on expensive things reduces financial pressure. Couples who can enjoy simple pleasures together have more relationship resilience.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different beliefs about what's needed for happiness reflect different values. Explore what each partner truly needs to feel content.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared belief in happiness without expensive things creates financial flexibility.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What brings you happiness that doesn't cost much? Does your partner value the same things?

questions.text: I believe we agree on what's worth spending extra money on.

therapeutic.rationale: Agreement on what's worth premium spending—quality food, experiences, comfort, convenience—reflects shared values about what matters.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different priorities about 'worth spending on' often reflect different upbringings or values. Neither is wrong; both need respect.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared priorities about where to spend extra create natural alignment in financial decisions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's worth spending extra money on to you? Where do you prefer to economize?

questions.text: I feel comfortable with the lifestyle we can realistically afford.

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort with your realistic lifestyle—not aspirational or inflated—creates contentment. Chronic dissatisfaction with what's affordable breeds resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner is less comfortable with your realistic lifestyle, explore what feels lacking. Is it about circumstances or expectations?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared comfort with your realistic lifestyle creates contentment and reduces financial pressure.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Are you content with the lifestyle you can actually afford? What would help?
